review.title: Trolls Identification within an Uncertain Framework
review.abstract: The web plays an important role in people's social lives since the emergence of Web 2.0. It facilitates the interaction between users, gives them the possibility to freely interact, share and collaborate through social networks, online communities forums, blogs, wikis and other online collaborative media. However, an other side of the web is negatively taken such as posting inflammatory messages. Thus, when dealing with the online communities forums, the managers seek to always enhance the performance of such platforms. In fact, to keep the serenity and prohibit the disturbance of the normal atmosphere, managers always try to novice users against these malicious persons by posting such message (DO NOT FEED TROLLS). But, this kind of warning is not enough to reduce this phenomenon. In this context we propose a new approach for detecting malicious people also called 'Trolls' in order to allow community managers to take their ability to post online. To be more realistic, our proposal is defined within an uncertain framework. Based on the assumption consisting on the trolls' integration in the successful discussion threads, we try to detect the presence of such malicious users. Indeed, this method is based on a conflict measure of the belief function theory applied between the different messages of the thread. In order to show the feasibility and the result of our approach, we test it in different simulated data.

sections.text: In this section, we present some concepts related to Q & AC: first, we introduce the main players in these forums, then a brief overview of the identification of sources, and finally, the degree of uncertainty we face in Q & AC.

sections.heading: C. Uncertainty within Q&AC
sections.text: Gjergji et al. have proposed three levels for Q & AC [11]: the first refers to the extraction and integration of uncertainty, the second to the uncertainty of information sources and finally to the knowledge inherent in the information itself. In our case, we are more interested in the evaluation of the sources and the part of uncertainty associated with them. The main problem in these communities is that we are dealing with users about whom we do not always know in advance. We ignore everything that has to do with the credibility, reliability, relevance, objectivity and expertise of the sources. In this context, we will use the entire mathematical background and the large panel of sepcificities provided by the theory of faith functions to help us look at this problem from an uncertain point of view.

sections.heading: V. TROLLS IDENTIFICATION BASED IN A CONFLICT MEASURE
sections.text: Based on the assumption that the integration of trolls into the successful threads of discussion, we propose a new method for detecting malicious persons in online community forums. This approach is defined within the framework of faith functions and is in fact based on a conflict measurement of this theory applied between the various messages of the thread. We can summarize our proposed method in three broad steps, which will be discussed in detail below.

sections.text: The final step is to classify the users according to their conflict outcomes into two groups. To make a decision, we are based on an uncontrolled classification method introduced by McQueen [19] and implemented by Forgy [20] in its current form. Kmeans algorithm aims to construct clusters of partitions (clusters) concentrated from the objects of training group K. In our case, we will divide the users into two partitions: K = 2. Since the value of the conflict of the troll is greater than the conflict of the other users: - Trolls belong to the group with the highest value of the centre. - The other users belong to the group with the lowest value of the centre.

sections.heading: VII. CONCLUSION
sections.text: Our work is based on a measure of conflict in the belief function theory used between messages from the various users of the thread. Firstly, this method aims to analyze messages in relation to the question or topic posted, but recognizing irrelevant messages is not enough to determine whether or not that user is a troll. Thus, not only the content of messages that can characterize the trolls, but also their behavior. Next, we measured the conflict between different users based on the results of this analysis. Finally, after calculating each user's conflict, we used the Kmeans method to distinguish trolls from other users. In fact, we classified users into two clusters according to their conflict outcomes. This method was tested in various simulated data to verify its feasibility. As our proposed method of detecting this malicious method aimed to detect only one thread within the community.
